text: when they hit you it sounded like a
shotgun going off over the top of your
head I took 37 licks my legs were
shaking and he said look at me boy and
he was smile and he was grinning Allen
Sexton is one of hundreds of men who say
they were brutally punished while they
were students at the Dozier school for
boys in Marianna Florida they were all
taken here into the building known as
the White House to receive their
beatings citing economic reasons the
state shut down the school in 2011 the
campus is now abandoned the buildings
are in disrepair but stories of the
abuse have led to an ambitious project
to exhume the remains of boys who died
while living at the Dozier school these
children came here and for one reason or
another didn't ever go home again
Erin Kimberly is a forensic
anthropologist who worked in the mass
graves of Bosnia now she's at Dozier
hoping to return the remains of these
children to their families in all of the
cases that I've worked both locally here
in Florida and internationally
it's about human identification which is
for families and I think that that's
what is a common denominator is that you
have siblings parents you know relatives
asking for information for their remains
back and it's that's their right it's a
pretty basic right over the school's
100-year history children died due to
fire flu fights and accidents but
there's no record of who's buried where
55 bodies have been exhumed from the
cemetery dogs and radar are being used
to check other locations on the school's
1400 acre campus the goal now is to
confirm the cause of death and identify
the remains on Tuesday Kimberly released
a composite image of one of the boys
buried in the cemetery it was created
using reassembled skull fragments she
also updated the list of relatives who
have been contacted as part of the
identification process one of those is
Priscilla Krauser whose brother died in
a fight he was stabbed many times
that is filtered down through the years
but the family evidently never received
the body and in those days 76 years ago
you didn't ask questions a lot of
intimidation family members and former
students hope that the dig will provide
answers about what happened here at the
Dozier school but some local residents
say the truth about the cemetery is much
less mysterious than it seems the big
misconceptions about the cemetery is
that it was hidden or that these are
mystery graves local historian Dale Cox
says it wasn't uncommon for schools like
Dozier to have on-site cemeteries and
the digging of the bodies is
disrespectful the cemetery has been a
known part of the community for over 100
years and most of the graves in the
cemetery predate 1940 in fact I think
there were three from within the last 75
years you know it's said that it's just
this lost hidden mystery cemetery out in
the woods but it was never hidden it had
a fence around it it was maintained and
we know who was buried in it but for
Kimberly it's not enough to know the
names of the boys who were buried at
Dozier she wants to put those names with
the right remains and ultimately send
them home Kate Daly BBC news Marianna
Florida
